TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesday: User Interfaces and Workspaces

Articles.Content:
<figure data-orig-width="480" data-orig-height="92" class="tmblr-full"></figure>Things are moving along at Squad this week. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re in the final stages of a process that brings us to the first QA tests of update 1.1!

Felipe (HarvesteR) has been working on the user interface for the map view and the orbit rendering in it. The orbit rendering is one of the most complex systems in the game and quite a tangle of code to unravel, but like many of the other parts of the game weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve tackled due to the update to Unity 5 itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been needing a rewrite for a good while now.

Last week we talked about the toolkit that is used to draw the orbit lines, Vectrosity. We mentioned that it had been updated to accommodate Unity 5Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s new user interface system and that we had to rewrite large parts of our code to make everything work again, and it turns out it took even more than we had originally anticipated. Felipe ended up editing of the toolkit source code as well because KSPÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s map view isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t a Ã¢â‚¬ËœnormalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ game setup: there are several cameras at work, rendering from different layers in different coordinate frames, and the splines fall right in that weird in-between zone which isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t easily identifiable as a worldspace object, nor as a screenspace one, because in a way theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re both.

These cameras render in screenspace, but they take coordinates from worldspace points, and depending on the map zoom, they shift from rendering in a 2D canvas to a 3D one. Long story short: itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s complicated. Ultimately, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re working again and even got a few improvements.

With the orbit splines taken care of weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve moved on to the map icons. These are the graphics that are drawn on top of the orbits and show your position, apoapsis, close approaches, intercepts and so on. In the old system we relied on one method called GUI.draw to draw all these icons onto the screen, and while it was a quick way to produce UI controls quickly it also meant that we lost a lot of control over the objects that were being drawn.

In the new user interface system each icon and other UI control point is its own actual object, which means we can spawn and remove them, (de)attach them or send information to them from the orbit renderer, and on top of that they all handle their control inputs autonomously. Ultimately this is a good thing, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s also a major revision of the interface logic for orbits and map objects in general. Implementing this new system in a way that can integrate into the bits we want to keep from the old one is a large and ongoing task, but ultimately itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be worth it.

While Felipe has been working on the map view interface Jim (Romfarer) has been working on the staging interface this week. The backend code of this part of the game is yet another part that was in need of a critical look, and heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s now working to make the user interface talk with the underlying systems in a reliable way.

Aside from all the ongoing work on the gameÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s interface, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re planning to implement a number of features to improve the accessibility of the game, making the game easier for complete novices through a number of methods. Mike (Mu) has been coming up with some great and interesting ideas in this area and although nothing is definitive yet we should be able to bring you some news on this over the coming weeks. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve also heard heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s very happy with the new computer heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s built, which has improved his compile times immensely.

Speaking of workstations, Ted finished up moving house this week, got his new workplace all set up and is ready to dive back into the swing of things. Most of his time was spent in the Ã¢â‚¬Ëœdaily grindÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and updating the internal documentation in preparation for the upcoming QA of update 1.1. As we progress through the development of 1.1, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s becoming more clear where the growing pains and areas of issue are, so modifications to the documentation are made to provide the QA team with a solid foundation to start testing soon.

Friday was a very interesting day at Squad for many reasons. Firstly, the Squadcast was hosted not by Miguel (Maxmaps), but by Kasper, Ted and Andrea (Badie). In a mission that Ted described as Ã¢â‚¬Å“brilliantÃ¢â‚¬Â and Kasper as Ã¢â‚¬Å“typical SquadcastÃ¢â‚¬Â a rocket blew up on the first attempt due to lack of struts, then at the second attempt it made a full 360 degree flip on its way to orbit and ultimately landed safely at Duna, only to see the payload explode at the very end of the mission.

Where was Miguel then? He had caught a plane to the PAX Prime convention in Seattle for then mysterious purposes. By now everyone probably knows he was there to announce the Wii U port of KSP during NintendoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬ËœNindies at NightÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ event. HeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s back with us now and although he had a great time at the event he seems to have contracted the zombie plague, no doubt from the many handshakes, high-fives and hugs he received from fans and developers at the convention.

This week both Kasper and Marco (MarcoSS) have started their university curricula again, and both in the Netherlands! Marco is there to obtain his masterÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s degree in Game and Media Technology, while Kasper is shooting for his masterÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s degree in Criminology. We wish both of them the best of luck! TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll still be around here of course, unless theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re meeting up for drinks as students often do.

ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s it for this weekÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s devnotes, let us know if you have any questions about the topics we touched on!

It gets hard really quickly. Example: your upper stage vessel that has stages 6 through 8 (information which now has to be stored into the persistence file) docks with another vessel that has stages 7-10. What is the staging on the resulting vessel? I'm sure that type of problem is solvable - but I just don't see the benefit given the increased complexity required.
Kasper is getting a masters in criminology? *hides in a dark corner of Dre's(no body goes there he won't notice me)*

I like this, the first stage that fires... is the first stage

Maybe it's just me, but I like the current stages. The top stage is... the top stage it's easier to keep track of as well when creating your ship design, or when jettisoning stages, since you're counting down to your last stage.

Secondly, it's easier to keep tabs especially on large ships. Pretend we did it your way where you counted up. The final stage being the highest. Say you have 25 stages. Stage 25 is your last stage. You're on stage 13 atm.. How many stages do you have left? Sure it's a simple mathematical equation 25 - 13 = 12, you got 12 stages left.

With the current way, you don't need to do that, you'll be on stage 12, telling you you got 12 stages left. No need to do the middle man of math albeit simple. I also know that I need to be at my destination in orbit by stage 10, or I'm screwed and didn't do it right. If again, we did it your way, I'd have to yet again do another silly little mathematical equation to figure out which # is 10 down the row.

Conclusion: Current way works perfectly, your suggestion.. is just silly.. Yes, sure it may confuse new players.. for a day.. but really? a nice tutorial can fix that immediately, and the problems it'd create reversing the numbering on stages would create even more catastrophic problems for new players worse than the simple 1 day confusion on staging numbering.

Talking about map mode, there are a lot of improvements that are really needed:

- Map mode is for navigation and maps usually are readable. But how are you supposed to navigate, when dark sides of planets and moons are as black as in the 'real' game? Please add some ambient light to map view of planets so that i actually know where KSC is at when it's on the dark side.
